question.questionA: Florets bisexual; spikelets all similar; fruit not enclosed in a utricle.
question.questionB: Florets  unisexual,  in  separate male  and  female  spikelets,  or  on different parts of the same spikelet; fruit enclosed in a utricle.

question.questionA: Spikelets laterally compressed, florets and glumes in two ranks.
question.questionB: Spikelets not laterally compressed, florets and glumes in three ranks or spirally arranged.

question.questionA: Inflorescence subtended by one leafy bract; spikelets of one to four fertile florets.
question.questionB: Inflorescence  subtended by  two  to  six  leafy bracts;  spikelets of twenty to thirty fertile florets.

question.questionA: Stems up to 50 cm, often leafless; inflorescence a bundle of one to forty sessile spikelets; spikelets elongated and often curved.
question.questionB: Stems  often  exceeding  50  cm,  leafy;  inflorescence a simple or compound umbel; spikelets straight.

question.questionA: Stems up to 150 cm; rhizomes 3-10 mm wide; spikelets radiating to form a globular cluster.
question.questionB: Stems up to 60 cm; rhizomes c. 1 mm wide; spikelets more or less erect.

question.questionA: Spikelets few-flowered, with five to seven glumes only the upper and longer one to three being fertile.
question.questionB: Spikelets usually many-flowered; glumes usually all fertile  and equal, or the lower glumes longer than the upper.

question.questionA: Spikelets solitary, terminal; uppermost leaf  sheath without a green blade.
question.questionB: Spikelets usually clustered, if   solitary  and  terminal   the uppermost leaf sheath with a green blade.

question.questionA: Caespitose annuals; spikelets solitary, terminal; the uppermost leaf sheath bearing a green blade.
question.questionB: Rhizomatous perennials; spikelets clustered.

question.questionA: Spikelets globose.
question.questionB: Spikelets ovoid.

question.questionA: Stems terete.
question.questionB: Stems trigonous.

question.questionA: Stems  leafy; longest bracts much exceeding the terminal inflorescence; spikelets 8- 45 mm long.
question.questionB: Stems  leaf less, or upper sheath with short blade; longest bracts equally  or  just  exceeding  the terminal   inflorescence;  spikelets 5-15 mm long.

question.questionA: Spikes all similar, the upper part with male florets, the lower with female florets.
question.questionB: Spikes dissimilar, the upper spikes usually entirely male and the lower spikes entirely female.

question.questionA: Inflorescence lax, at least the lower spikes widely spaced and not overlapping.
question.questionB: Inflorescence dense, most spikelets overlapping.

question.questionA: Spikes few, widely spaced, each subtended by a leafy bract which exceeds the inflorescence.
question.questionB: Spikes numerous, only the lowest subtended by a prominent bract and this not exceeding the inflorescence.

question.questionA: Tussock-forming perennials, up to 100 cm; spikes all similar; bracts linear, recurved; utricles yellowish green.
question.questionB: Rhizomatous perennials,  up  to  80  cm; uppermost spike often entirely male; bracts lanceolate, erect; utricles reddish brown.

question.questionA: Rhizomatous perennials up to 100 cm; spikes more  than ten times as long as broad, cylindrical, the upper male the lower female but often with male florets towards the top; utricles plano-convex with bristly teeth on the margin.
question.questionB: Plants not exceeding 50 cm; the female spikes less than five times as long as broad, normally without male florets at the top.

question.questionA: Inflorescence very compact, all florets overlapping.
question.questionB: Inflorescence lax, at least the lower spikes widely spaced and not overlapping.

question.questionA: Slender  caespitose  perennials;  lower  bract  not  exceeding  the inflorescence.
question.questionB: Slender rhizomatous perennials; lower bract greatly exceeding the inflorescence.

question.questionA: Female  spikes  lax,  on  filiform  nodding  peduncles,  very widely spaced.
question.questionB: Female  spikes dense, sessile or on stout erect peduncles, often overlapping.

question.questionA: Leaves dark green above, glaucous below; female spikes dark brown, more than twice as long as wide, pedunculate.
question.questionB: Leaves green; female spikes green, less than twice as long as wide, the lower pedunculate the upper sessile.
